original_content:
Many things have combined to make very high-frequency RF gear much more common, cheaper, and better performing. Case in point: [dereksgc] is tearing apart a 20 GHz low-noise block (LNB). An LNB is a downconverter, and this one is used for some Irish satellite TV services.
The scale of everything matters when your wavelength is only 15 mm. The PCB is small and neatly laid out. There are two waveguides printed on the board, each feeding essentially identical parts of the PCB. Printed filters use little patterns on the board that have particular inductance and capacitance  no need for any components. Try doing that at 2 MHz!
The LNB is a single-band unit, so it only needs to worry about the two polarizations. However, [dereksgc] shows that some have multiple bands, which makes everything more complex. He also mentions that this LNB doesnt use a PLL, and hed like to find a replacement at this frequency that is a bit more modern.
After the teardown, it is time to test the device to see how it works. If you want to experiment at this frequency, you need special techniques. For example, weve seen people try to push solderless breadboards this high (spoiler: it isnt easy). Maybe thats why many people settle for modifying existing LNBs like this one.
title: - 20GHzの低雑音ブロック（LNB）の内部を解剖
body: 高周波RF機器が一般的になり、20GHzの低雑音ブロックが解体され、特性や測定方法が紹介されている。
titles: - 20GHzの低雑音ブロック（LNB）の内部を解剖
- 高周波RF機器の進化：手頃な価格で高性能化
- 小型PCBと印刷フィルターのインパクトを理解する
- LNBの複数帯域設計の複雑さに迫る
- 高周波実験に必要な特殊技術とその挑戦
